p.s: In the course of the scene certain elements are to be observed which describe the way Starr perceives Chris and in which state their current relationship is.
The director uses several devices to present Chris from the point of view of Starr.
Starr who is annoyed and upset by Chris on the surface loves Chris and puts up this act due to not wanting to be treated badly by her boyfriend.
The scene mainly consists of long shots in a eye-level or low angle with the camera following each of his interactions when portraying Chris.
That way, the spectator observes ChrisesChris' sociability and general superficial character traits that can be concluded by things such as the accessoires he wears or his gesture.
The low-angle shots let Chris stand out from the other people.

That way the director points out StarrsStarr's attention focusing on only her boyfriend, which is stressed through little to no noise and the blurred portrayal of other students in the school as well.
While Starr is watching Chris, each shot is in slow motion.
This visual effect emphasizes Starr drifting away from reality with only Chris filling her mind.
This effect is underlined by the music as well, which sounds soft and admiring while at the same time lively and not warm nor cold.
The music perfectly portrays Starr's current position towards Chris: She is torn between her cold facade towards him and her actual feelings.

This pretentious coldness is supported by the colour scheme of the sequence: It consists of only cool toned greens and blues which is another factor that proves StarrsStarr's attitude at Williamson is adding on to her current conflict.

Chris then spots Starr, the slow motion stops and the camera abruptly shifts from Chris to Starr, who snaps out of her admiring thoughts and breaks the eye contact and tries to act unbothered by Chris' presence through packing her bag.
Chris approaches Starr who is then only seen a big close up turned away from Chris.

The spectator can now observe her true reaction to Chris' track after he puts his headphones on Starr, which is positive, opposing her/following words that don't reflect her shown emotions, which breaks the moment breaks when Starr looks Chris in the face and acts upset.
They both then have a talk and the more their discussion goes into depth, the closer gets the camera to their faces to portray their emotions and the way thethey see each other.
The atmosphere then continues to change to Starr's point of view which is contradicted in slow motion.

Every time this mood sets in, Starr's thoughts are heard which all consist of ChrisesChris' positive traits and prove her true feelings for him and all the other sounds and people are being blurred out.

When their conversation reaches the end, Starr begins to avoid eye contact since she is unable to upheld the fassadefacade of being upset any longer and tries to suppress her increasing amount of smiles.
But Starr lets this pretence fall down through laughing when Chris begins to dance.
He dances for her while making a fool of himself which proves his love to Starr and assures her that she is important to him.

In conclusion, the stated hypothesis turns out to be proven through many symbols that are cold such as lighting but are disproven by Starr's actual reaction towards Chris which she tries to cover by a pretence until it falls down at last.
A possible assumption is that Starr puts up this act to find out whether Chris is truly sorry and will treat her better in the future since it is obvious that she is not deeply upset.
